  object_colour: multicoloured

  physical_appearance: This is a Ming dynasty Zhangzhou ware
 evidenced by the grit on the base of the dish. The upper and lower rim of its exterior surface is decorated with simple blue lines
 while its interior decorative scheme is composed of floral motifs and sprays segmented in three concentric bands.

  subject_terms_1: porcelain paintings (visual works)  symbolism  floral patterns  freehand drawings (drawings)  Chinese export porcelain

 Chinese Ming- Qing dynasties

  subject_terms_3: visual arts  Decorative arts Ceramics

  subject_terms_4: 

  sgcool_label_text: This dish is decorated with floral sprays arranged in three concentric bands. The thick potting
 sketchily-rendered decoration and gritty base of this dish indicates that it was produced at the Zhangzhou kilns in Fujian province. Grit often adhered to the foot of Zhangzhou wares as the pieces were placed directly on the coarse sand (spread on the bottom of the saggar) while they were still wet with glaze. Zhangzhou wares
 which are distinguished by their free and vigorous style of painted decoration
 were a popular type of ceramics made for export during the late Ming dynasty.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: This dish is decorated with floral sprays arranged in three concentric bands. The thick potting, sketchily-rendered decoration and gritty base of this dish indicates that it was produced at the Zhangzhou kilns in Fujian province. Grit often adhered to the foot of Zhangzhou wares as the pieces were placed directly on the coarse sand (spread on the bottom of the saggar) while they were still wet with glaze. Zhangzhou wares, which are distinguished by their free and vigorous style of painted decoration, were a popular type of ceramics made for export during the late Ming dynasty.
